I saw that the above named errors of Brother Bates [his position on helping the poor; praying for the sick before unbelievers] and others more dangerous brought confusion and had destroyed James's confidence in Brother Bates; I saw that James at first had godly jealousy for the truth, then other jealousy crept in until he was jealous of most every move Brother Bates would 


                                   -437- 

make. These wrongs I saw must be taken out of the way.--Ms 14, 1850, p. 2. (General manuscript from Hiram Edson's manuscript, September, 1850.)
